description:
Anopheles arabiensis is a species of mosquito that belongs to the Anopheles genus, which is the primary vector of malaria parasites. It is a member of the Anopheles gambiae complex, a group of closely related mosquito species that are considered major malaria vectors in Africa.

Anopheles arabiensis is found predominantly in sub-Saharan Africa, with a distribution that spans from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia in the east, and as far south as South Africa. It is known to be an efficient vector of Plasmodium falciparum, the most deadly species of malaria parasite affecting humans.

Morphologically, Anopheles arabiensis is similar to other members of the Anopheles gambiae complex, with a slender body and long, delicate legs. It can be distinguished from other species in the complex by specific characteristics, such as the pattern of pale and dark scales on its wings.

Ecologically, Anopheles arabiensis is adapted to a variety of breeding habitats, including temporary and semi-permanent water bodies, such as pools, puddles, and rice fields. It is considered a zoophilic species, meaning it prefers to feed on animals, but it can also feed on humans, making it an important disease vector.

Anopheles arabiensis is the subject of extensive research, as understanding its biology, behavior, and ecology is crucial for the development of effective malaria control strategies in areas where it is prevalent.
